editor OF Coram's Champion in New York. has pub
lished an article in the Alexandra Gazette in which
he declares, tha, an attempt to make fosl Of him
was once made by means Of letters written by some
OF MIR. Calhoun's creatures, and frnnksd BY Mr..
Calhoun himseli. The mnjor then saith, that were
he capable Of becoming tool, he should have en-


listed in Mr.. Calhoun's service, because he paid
his tools better than any other man, out of Uncle
SANS treasury" The Major then doth moreover
affirm ,ha, the rule observed hy General Duff Green,
editor o. the Jackson Warrington Telegraph, is
to lie, in where to speak the truth would
better serve his rn."-Thus do The officers Of the
General Jackson Corps, incon.ineny 20 to war with
each other; thus do they give the public their own
opinions Of each other, and thus the public not
to give credit to any Of them. Dem. Press.

Mr.. EDITOR Reports appear 10 be carefully
circulated among members Of Congress and others,
that New Jersey, at the next Presidents election,
will give its electoral vote to Gen. Jackson The au
thors OF such untounded declarations must take
counsel from their Wishss rather than their know
ledge, when they hazard such an opnsn. From an
intimate acqusin,snee with the people of that State
in oil s counties, from AZ extensive rrespondenee
carried on with gentlemen OF intelligence in each Of
those countless frsn personal observation, and the
most correct data that indubi,abc evidence can fur
nsh, the writer Of this solemnly auers, that a,
no antecedent period has the cause OF the Admins
traton stood fair in that State il does pres
en-. AT the last Congressional election, when the
parties were fairly arrayed, when the tickets we're
headed with the names OF jackson or .gdams. and
every possible efor! used by the friends OF the
tormer to elect their candidates, the result was
majority OF $500 votes in favor OF the Administra-
ton ticket and had the friends OF the Adminisra-
tim exerted themselves they eugh, to have done
IN all the counties the majority would have been
iwelled 10 at east 10000. Eleven out of the four
teen counties gave majorites for the Administrator
candidates. With such result before them, the
friends OF General Jackson mus. be literally mad 10
claim NewJersey as an Opposition State. Since
then, the writer Of this is well assured that the csuse
OF the Administraten has been growing in New.
Jersey. and that many active and influential men
have signi6ed their appreciation Of its measures and
are prepared 10 give it their most cordial support
II the reelection OF Mr.. Adams depends upon New
Jersey, it is as infaitibly certain as any future
event can be. To General Jackson, as brave ans
successful commander, tho people of New-Jersey
are friendly; but from him ~ a candidate for lhs
Presidency, their attachments have long since beer
Withdrawn.

The committee TO whom was referred the memo.
rial Of " The Visitors and Governors OF Washing
ton College, in The State Of Maryland" have had

some influence in their for nation and il strength
ems tbs energies OF governmsnt by enlistng in its
auppor, . greater ms.a Of intellectual force.


These considerations entle it TO the highest re-
gard from ssery enlightened community. but more
especially from one whose government is maintain
ed by a representation mutable in its nature. and
selected indiscriminately from the great body Of
che people.


And whereas, the college at Chester town. honor

as we'll into Souncs, over the state at large
aud the buildings Of this institution having recently

whereas, from the petition Of the Visitors and Gov
ernors Of this institution, and from the known wish.
es and arden, desires OF large portion Of the
community on this subject, is believed TO be proper,
and in high degree wise and polite, for the sate
20 appropriate fund tor rebuilding this edihce,
which, when erected, was designed by i.s immedi
ate founders, and BY the intelligent legislature oi
our aiate, to be in honorable and perpetual memory
Of the illustrious and vir,uous Washington there
fore,


Resolved, That the treasurer OF the Western
ahere be and he is hereby authorized and required
to pay unto "ths Visitor. and Governors OF Wash.
ingten College in the State Of Maryland or to
their order, the sum Of ten thousand dollars, the
same 10 be paid in the following manner viz. The
aum of Ave thousand dollars on the hrst day o
May in the year 1928 the sum Of two thousant
Eve hundred dollars on the 6rs. day Of May in the

dred dollars ON the hrst day of May in the year
1880.


Resolved. Tha, when ihe said full sum Of ter
thousand dollars shall be received BY the said Viii

ment, satisfaction and dischsrge OF all claim ane
demand whatsoever. which "the Visitors and Gov
ernors OF Warrington College in the State o

Jackson in Ksntucky. The Legislature OF Ken
lucky adjourned on the 25th Of January. II is gen.
orally known that an attempt was made TO bring that
body out against the administration and in avor OF
Gen. Jackson, II may not be amiss to give briei
statement of the proceeding.


The Tennessee amendment Of the constitution OF
the United States was set foot 40 kind OF enter
ing wedge for the General. Accordingly his sup.
porters broug il, before the legislature OF Kentucky
al their late session. The Senate passed resolutions
recommending the amendment. They were amen
ded in the House, passed and sent back to the Senate
for concurrence in the amendments. They were
laid on the table in the Senats, and remained there
when the session ended.


One OF the amendments made in the House, was
the insertion Of proviso in The following words:


Provided, that nothing in the foregoing resolu.
en s intended to convey the idea that the charges
Of corruption which have been imputed TO the pre-





election OF Presden at the late election BY congress
arc founded in truth, or are believed by this Gene
raj Assembly."


This provso was adopted in the House by vote
OF 81 TO As.


While the subject was under discussion, another
provso was offered asserting that the resolution OF
the Legislature, in 1924, declaring that majority
Of the people preferred General Jackson, was true.


This proyiso was laid upon The table until the frs.
- Tkns o fks
Legislature Of Kentucky have indicated pretty
strongly, that they are not yet prepared to 60 for
the Hero. And majority Of the House have pro-
nounced the often repeated charge Of corruption in
the Presidential election to be . ialsehood.

| From Louisiana, we received some days sgo, the
Message Of her worthy Governor, Henry johnson,
a, the opening Of the Session cf the Legislature II
is distinguished BY all those amiable and benevolent

but are prevented BY the want Of room. The fol-
lowing extract is, however, so short that We may ven
ture 10 insert III a. being that part OF ths Message
which bears Immediately upon tho concerns OF the
General Government:-- Vat Intelligencer.
"The condition OF the United States 10 preem-
nently happy and prosperous. They continue to
advance rapidly IN population, IN wealth. IN power,
in responsibility The last half ceRtury has wilneAD-
ed immense Improvements in science, literature,
and oil the arts. The success Of our political sy..
tenn has been commensurate with the expectations.
and smost with the wishes of It's llustrous Trainers
United under the principles Of the Federal Consti-
tuition, we he under TWO fold obligation to support
the National Government in al it's constitutional
iuncons and TO msin,ain, at the same time, the
rights of the States. The one 10 intimately blended
with our existence IS powerful nation the other
is indispensable TO the preservation Of free Govern
ment.


" In The attsc hment Of the People TO the Union
in the wisdom and integrity OF the men in whom
they conhde in the eoun,cr-poise OF reciprocal au-
shori,es and dependencies, have security sgains
all encroschments Of any portion Of Inc community
upon the rights Of another And while the Gene
raj Government is lsboring TO preserve honor able
peace with foreign nations, and. by wise inca.
sures OF administration, to promote prosperity al
home, il is incumbent W to use every effort to
render our local Institutions perfee, ~ possible .

better serve his rn."-Thus do The officers Of the
General Jackson Corps, incon.ineny 20 to war with
each other; thus do they give the public their own
opinions Of each other, and thus the public not
to give credit to any Of them. Dem. Press.

full articles.headline: From the National Journal.
full articles.article:
Mr.. EDITOR Reports appear 10 be carefully
circulated among members Of Congress and others,
that New Jersey, at the next Presidents election,
will give its electoral vote to Gen. Jackson The au
thors OF such untounded declarations must take
counsel from their Wishss rather than their know
ledge, when they hazard such an opnsn. From an
intimate acqusin,snee with the people of that State
in oil s counties, from AZ extensive rrespondenee
carried on with gentlemen OF intelligence in each Of
those countless frsn personal observation, and the
most correct data that indubi,abc evidence can fur
nsh, the writer Of this solemnly auers, that a,
no antecedent period has the cause OF the Admins
traton stood fair in that State il does pres
en-. AT the last Congressional election, when the
parties were fairly arrayed, when the tickets we're
headed with the names OF jackson or .gdams. and
every possible efor! used by the friends OF the
tormer to elect their candidates, the result was
majority OF $500 votes in favor OF the Administra-
ton ticket and had the friends OF the Adminisra-
tim exerted themselves they eugh, to have done
IN all the counties the majority would have been
iwelled 10 at east 10000. Eleven out of the four
teen counties gave majorites for the Administrator
candidates. With such result before them, the
friends OF General Jackson mus. be literally mad 10
claim NewJersey as an Opposition State. Since
then, the writer Of this is well assured that the csuse
OF the Administraten has been growing in New.
Jersey. and that many active and influential men
have signi6ed their appreciation Of its measures and
are prepared 10 give it their most cordial support
II the reelection OF Mr.. Adams depends upon New
Jersey, it is as infaitibly certain as any future
event can be. To General Jackson, as brave ans
successful commander, tho people of New-Jersey
are friendly; but from him ~ a candidate for lhs
Presidency, their attachments have long since beer
Withdrawn.


A JERSEYMAN.
Washington, Jan. 80.

full articles.headline:
LEGISLATURE OF MARYLAND.
House Of Delegates-Feb. 9, 1897.
full articles.article:
Mr.. Boon, az chairman OF the committee therein
mentioned, delivered a report, recommending the
adoption oi the accompanying preamble and rsso
lutions; which we're read, laid the table, and are
a. follow, via.


The committee TO whom was referred the memo.
rial Of " The Visitors and Governors OF Washing
ton College, in The State Of Maryland" have had
the same under confederation, and recommend the
adoption Of the following preamble and resolutions :


Whereas the encouragement, Of literature in all
its branches, from the rudments 10 be taught in our
primary schools, to the more elevated and scientific
hbors oil collegiate course. 10 sublec, deeply al
fectng to the character and best interest OF free
state and there can, it 10 conceived, be national
undertaking better calculated TO insure the perms
nent prosperity Of the republic. 1t enhances the
value OF free institutions by making them better
understood it gives yigor to the laws by ii whole
some influence in their for nation and il strength
ems tbs energies OF governmsnt by enlistng in its
auppor, . greater ms.a Of intellectual force.


These considerations entle it TO the highest re-
gard from ssery enlightened community. but more
especially from one whose government is maintain
ed by a representation mutable in its nature. and
selected indiscriminately from the great body Of
che people.


And whereas, the college at Chester town. honor
ed by the veneralsd name of ths Father of his
Country, for some years past, notwithstanding The
feeble aid OF the state and the formidable obstacles
it conended with, had been dfusing its blessings,
as we'll into Souncs, over the state at large
aud the buildings Of this institution having recently
been destroyed BY FIRE, Communicated, ~ is conf
IDENTIFY believed, By the hand of an ineendiary And
whereas, from the petition Of the Visitors and Gov
ernors Of this institution, and from the known wish.
es and arden, desires OF large portion Of the
community on this subject, is believed TO be proper,
and in high degree wise and polite, for the sate
20 appropriate fund tor rebuilding this edihce,
which, when erected, was designed by i.s immedi
ate founders, and BY the intelligent legislature oi
our aiate, to be in honorable and perpetual memory
Of the illustrious and vir,uous Washington there
fore,


Resolved, That the treasurer OF the Western
ahere be and he is hereby authorized and required
to pay unto "ths Visitor. and Governors OF Wash.
ingten College in the State Of Maryland or to
their order, the sum Of ten thousand dollars, the
same 10 be paid in the following manner viz. The
aum of Ave thousand dollars on the hrst day o
May in the year 1928 the sum Of two thousant
Eve hundred dollars on the 6rs. day Of May in the
year 1893: and the sum OF two thousand FIVE hun
dred dollars ON the hrst day of May in the year
1880.


Resolved. Tha, when ihe said full sum Of ter
thousand dollars shall be received BY the said Viii
tors and Governors the same shall be in full pay
ment, satisfaction and dischsrge OF all claim ane
demand whatsoever. which "the Visitors and Gov
ernors OF Warrington College in the State o
Maryland" may or can have under, or by virtue o
the act. entitled. " An ACT to provide permanen
fund for the further enc oursgement and establish
men, Of Washington College," passed at Novsm
hsr session 1884, chapter Z.

One circumstance Of the history Of the Vice Presidents
appeal cannot fail strike every reader The report Of
the Committee read to hs House Of Representatives

position Of it which retained within the power, and placed
il among the pending business Of the House It being,

sumption of the Chair remsre end not reconcilea

We have before US . most interesting letter from
an American Lady, written at +" Lagrange, Decem-
ber 9th, 1896" where she had, for some time, been
on 4 visit 10 the venerable and excellent Lafayette.
We have much pleasure in submitting the following
extracts. They rub out foul caumny which, We
are al loss 10 know upon wha, authority, has been
extensively circulated against the American people


Dem. Press.


by the American papers see, q letter said TO
DC written BY very respecisble gentleman, giving
an account OF visi, TO Lagrange: among numer
Gus errors in lhia production, there is one which has
given General Lafayette real pain. 1t 10 where the
writer says, he is iniormed that nine applications Is
had been made to the General for money, the pre-
cedlng week. by young men from the United States.
Last night, the General said, with much animation,
that this was as great mistake, as ever WAS made,
and that he had never had single application OF
that nature that tbs Young Americans Who had
called upon him, had uniformly conducted them.
selves with the creates, proprie.y, and tha, there
was no Foundation Whatever, for the report.


~ have, says the letter writer, seen enough oI
other parts OF the world to teach me 10 ioye nv own
country more, and TO estlmats its advantages high
er' every day. Ours may emphatieally be called
the Land OF Liberty. The truth il, we have &c
much freedom and so little opper tunity Of contrast
ing our condition with other ceuntries, that We dc
not sufficiently appreciate our happnsss. The yea
tor and love OF county, feel, makes me anxou,
that the above declaration of our beloved Genera
may be given in reEu,aon Of the libel which ha,
been published"

Washington, February l5-The Telegraph OF
Yesterday asserts that Mr.. Clay was in the House,
on Tuesday. 10 superintend the Report Of the MIX
Committee" We have good reasons lor stating
tha, Mr.. Clay did no, reach the House Of AsPre
scntaives until after that Report had been read and
that his visit to the Capitol was to see some speci-
mens OF American manufacture which wsrs exhlbi-
ted in the Ro,unda. A system Of espionage, more
remarkable for any thing than for the fidelity OF ts
reports, seems to be prac,ised in regard 10 every

practical results of those measures Tor the encsur'
agemcst si American industry, and the promotion
Of American greatness, TO which his abilities have
so long and so successfully been devoted.

Jackson in Ksntucky. The Legislature OF Ken
lucky adjourned on the 25th Of January. II is gen.
orally known that an attempt was made TO bring that
body out against the administration and in avor OF
Gen. Jackson, II may not be amiss to give briei
statement of the proceeding.


The Tennessee amendment Of the constitution OF
the United States was set foot 40 kind OF enter
ing wedge for the General. Accordingly his sup.
porters broug il, before the legislature OF Kentucky
al their late session. The Senate passed resolutions
recommending the amendment. They were amen
ded in the House, passed and sent back to the Senate
for concurrence in the amendments. They were
laid on the table in the Senats, and remained there
when the session ended.


One OF the amendments made in the House, was
the insertion Of proviso in The following words:


Provided, that nothing in the foregoing resolu.
en s intended to convey the idea that the charges
Of corruption which have been imputed TO the pre-





election OF Presden at the late election BY congress
arc founded in truth, or are believed by this Gene
raj Assembly."


This provso was adopted in the House by vote
OF 81 TO As.


While the subject was under discussion, another
provso was offered asserting that the resolution OF
the Legislature, in 1924, declaring that majority
Of the people preferred General Jackson, was true.


This proyiso was laid upon The table until the frs.
- Tkns o fks
Legislature Of Kentucky have indicated pretty
strongly, that they are not yet prepared to 60 for
the Hero. And majority Of the House have pro-
nounced the often repeated charge Of corruption in
the Presidential election to be . ialsehood.


Gin. Gns.
| From Louisiana, we received some days sgo, the
Message Of her worthy Governor, Henry johnson,
a, the opening Of the Session cf the Legislature II
is distinguished BY all those amiable and benevolent
traits which mark the msn. We should be glad 10
do BY it, by many Of the excellent Messages Tor
annual Exposes) Of the Executives Of the States
but are prevented BY the want Of room. The fol-
lowing extract is, however, so short that We may ven
ture 10 insert III a. being that part OF ths Message
which bears Immediately upon tho concerns OF the
General Government:-- Vat Intelligencer.
"The condition OF the United States 10 preem-
nently happy and prosperous. They continue to
advance rapidly IN population, IN wealth. IN power,
in responsibility The last half ceRtury has wilneAD-
ed immense Improvements in science, literature,
and oil the arts. The success Of our political sy..
tenn has been commensurate with the expectations.
and smost with the wishes of It's llustrous Trainers
United under the principles Of the Federal Consti-
tuition, we he under TWO fold obligation to support
the National Government in al it's constitutional
iuncons and TO msin,ain, at the same time, the
rights of the States. The one 10 intimately blended
with our existence IS powerful nation the other
is indispensable TO the preservation Of free Govern
ment.


" In The attsc hment Of the People TO the Union
in the wisdom and integrity OF the men in whom
they conhde in the eoun,cr-poise OF reciprocal au-
shori,es and dependencies, have security sgains
all encroschments Of any portion Of Inc community
upon the rights Of another And while the Gene
raj Government is lsboring TO preserve honor able
peace with foreign nations, and. by wise inca.
sures OF administration, to promote prosperity al
home, il is incumbent W to use every effort to
render our local Institutions perfee, ~ possible .
